text: The British biotechnology NN Microscience has announced successful trials of a JJ oral NN against enterotoxigenic E coli ( ETEC ) - the most significant NN of travellers ' diarrhoea . The NN produced protective immunity in 70 per cent of volunteers who took part in a NN conducted at St George 's Hospital , London . More NN is needed to establish the best dosing regime and the optimum NN schedule , and it is likely to take NNS for the product to become available commercially . However , the drug uses innovative technology that MD herald a JJ generation of needle - less NNS : Microscience is now working on oral prophylactics against typhoid , hepatitis B and RB anthrax . Another oral NN against ETEC MD be licensed in Britain in a matter of weeks . Dukoral is already available in several NNS , including Switzerland and Sweden . ETEC bacteria and cholera produce similar toxins which trigger the outpouring of fluid into the intestine that is characteristic of severe diarrhoea . Because Dukoral gives protection against this toxin , it has been licensed in some NNS as a NN for both cholera and ETEC diarrhoea . It has not yet been announced whether Dukoral will be licensed for both when it is launched in Britain . The old injection against cholera has not been available for NNS - and it gave negligible protection . Advances in medicine have made cholera a much less fearsome NN , but a JJ NN will be welcome , especially among intrepid travellers and those living and working in the developing NN . Travellers ' diarrhoea is a more widespread problem , afflicting at least CD - fifths of all international travellers . Although ETEC is the most common NN , it typically accounts for only about CD - fifths of NNS . The rest are caused by a vast range of bacteria , viruses and parasites - and there is no prospect of developing an effective NN against all of them . • Dr Dawood is a specialist in travel medicine at the Fleet Street Clinic , London ( 020 7353 5678 ) .

text: Early morning on NNP 18 , Moderna , a biotechnology NN , revealed the preliminary findings for the much anticipated phase I trial of an mRNA NN - CD NN . The NN sent Moderna ’s stock soaring by more than 20 % and helped fuel a rally on Wall Street . Although there was an enthusiastic response to the NN , the purpose of all phase I trials is primarily to demonstrate safety and tolerability . While the early results are tantalizingly positive , what Moderna has not revealed is raising some doubts . I am a data scientist and was , until last month , working on NN development for Zika and dengue fever . Since the beginning of the NN - CD NN , I have spearheaded building a consortium of more than 100 cancer centers to collect data about cancer patients who have been infected with NN - CD . The purpose of the NNP - CD and Cancer Consortium is to rapidly collect and disseminate NN about this especially vulnerable population . Having a background in NN development , I VBD Moderna ’s press release lacking some key details . A NN imitates the infection to give the immune system a preview of the NN . NN became a public NN tool after Edward Jenner showed in 1796 that inoculation with the less virulent cowpox MD prevent smallpox . After his son ’s death from smallpox , Benjamin Franklin regretted his decision not to inoculate his son against it . Today NNS are widely credited for the prevention and eradication of JJ of once feared deadly diseases . NNS prepare the immune system by generating NN - fighting proteins called antibodies , which seek out and attack if the real infectious NN ever shows up . Traditional NNS against viruses are either weakened versions of the whole NN that are unable to VB NN ; or they are made from signature viral proteins called antigens , that then spark an immune response . An antigen in the JJ NN NNP - CoV - 2 is the crown - JJ spike ( S ) protein through which the NN latches to the lung and respiratory cells . However , developing NNS based on the viral proteins is a slow process because of the difficulties in producing pure proteins at medical standards in JJ quantities . But now NNS have developed a different type of NN : mRNA NNS . Rather than giving a person a protein NN , researchers are giving them mRNA , which is the biological code that the cells read and translate to make their own proteins . So , instead of the traditional viral protein NNS , an mRNA NN provides a synthetic copy of mRNA - encoding individual proteins from the NN , which the host NN uses to produce the viral protein itself . As with other NNS , the presence of the protein kicks off the NN ’s immune system to fight the NN . A big advantage of mRNA NNS is that NNS can skip the laboratory production of proteins by directly injecting the molecular instructions to make the protein into the JJ NN itself . Massachusetts - based Moderna Inc. has fast - tracked development and testing of an experimental NN - CD mRNA NN called mRNA - 1273 . Its collaborators at the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases ( NIAID ) were already working on experimental Middle East respiratory syndrome ( MERS ) NNS , which targeted a closely related NN spike protein . So as soon as the genetic sequence of NNP - CoV - 2 became available , Moderna and its collaborators at NIAID got a head start . With up to US $ 483 million in federal funds to speed development of a NN NN , Moderna began testing the 2019 - nCoV NN ( mRNA - 1273 ) on Feb. 25 , 2020 . The phase 1 NN of the investigational NN , led by the NIAID , part of the National Institutes of NNP ( NIH ) , was designed to assess the safety , tolerability and ability to induce an immune response at three dose levels – 25 , 100 or 250 micrograms . On NNP 18 , Moderna announced the interim phase 1 data . mRNA -1273 was generally safe and well tolerated , except for minor redness and swelling at higher doses . No volunteers faced any NN - threatening events during the six weeks of NN . The mRNA - 1273 produced antibodies which MD bind the target spike protein at each of the injected doses , in all 45 volunteers ( ages 18 to 55 ) . The production of the binding antibodies response from mRNA - 1273 injection was similar to the NN VBN in patients who have recovered from previous NN - CoV - 2 infection . It is important to highlight , though , that RB among the survivors of NNP - CD , the antibody response is highly variable . What has not been revealed Unconventional for a scientific NN , data was given from only eight of the 45 volunteers — four each from the 25 and 100 microgram doses , who developed neutralizing antibodies . Neutralizing antibodies are essential for an effective JJ - lasting NN because they not only bind to the NN , but they block an infection . The age of the eight volunteers is not VBN . That is important NN because NNP - CD is far more deadly for older patients . It ’s important to VB if this immune response was limited to the younger participants . RB , the neutralizing antibody response in the remaining 37 volunteers was not disclosed . So it is impossible to VB whether the mRNA - 1273 was ineffective in them , or whether the results were not available at this point . The phase 2 trial for mRNA - 1273 has already been approved by the Food and Drug Administration . In this trial each subject will receive CD vaccinations – prime and booster – of either a placebo , a 50 microgram , or a 250 microgram dose given 28 days apart . The amended choice for a higher dose suggests that the lowest 25 microgram dose of phase 1 was not very effective . Moderna expects phase 3 trial to start in July and anticipates to produce 1 billion doses of the NN soon thereafter . [ VB facts about NN and the latest NN . text: Mainstream doctors and NN pundits are notorious for claiming that the NN - NN debate is over and that no legitimate scientific evidence exists to suggest RB a possible link between vaccinations and NN spectrum disorders ( ASD ) : case closed . But a thoroughly - researched report recently published by Arjun Walia over at Activist Post reveals that there are at least 22 published scientific studies that show a link between NNS and NN and that there are JJ more out there with similar findings . Much of the original controversy stems from Dr. Andrew Wakefield ’s NN RB in the late 1990s , which exposed gastrointestinal inflammation as an obvious side effect of NN with the combination NNS , mumps and rubella ( MMR ) NN . Dr. Wakefield obviously struck a major nerve with his NN , which was quickly torn apart by the establishment and maliciously paraded around as being fraudulent , RB though his groundbreaking findings have repeatedly been validated and replicated by JJ other studies . A 2002 NN published in the Journal of Biomedical Sciences , for instance , observed a causal effect between the MMR NN and NN , particularly with regards to the NNS portion of the NN . The researchers from Utah NNP NNP concluded that MMR is capable of inducing an abnormal NN infection in some NNS , which in turn can lead to neurological problems that fall under the umbrella of ASD . Another NN published in the journal Entropy in 2012 observed a strong correlation between the MMR NN and NN , except in this case aluminum was the culprit . According to an abstract of this NN , NNS that contain aluminum are particularly toxic to NNS , who end up later being diagnosed with ASD , as they have insufficient serum levels of both sulfate and glutathione . The aluminum VBN in some NNS , in other words , appears to be a primary aggravator of ASD NNS . “ Regardless of the MMR NN and NN debate , there are still a number of studies that link NNS to a possible NN connection , ” writes Walia . “ [ M]ultiple courts worldwide have ruled in favor of NNS causing NN , brain damage and other complications that include the MMR NN , ” he adds , noting that JJ other side effects besides NN have been observed in relation to NNS . Heavy metals , adjuvants , preservatives and other NN additives all linked to causing NN Perhaps the most interesting aspect of Walia ’s extensive NN on the subject is the fact that there appear to be multiple ingredients in NNS responsible for triggering NN . Besides toxic metals IN aluminum and mercury , NNS RB contain adjuvant materials , preservatives and other additives that have all been identified as culprits in the studies listed in his article . Realistically , each of these additives is most likely toxic both in isolation and in combination with the other additives , eliciting compounded toxicity depending on the mixture . “ Oxidative stress , brain inflammation and microgliosis have been much documented in association with toxic exposures including various heavy metals , ” admits CD NN out of Massachusetts General Hospital , which verified that autistic individuals possess a unique type of neuroinflammation in their brain tissue that points to NN damage . Several of the studies listed in Walia ’s report RB pin thimerosal , a toxic mercury derivative that is still being added to multidose vials of NN NN , as a trigger in causing the types of brain damage linked to NN . CD particular NN out of the NNP of Texas NNP NNP Center VBD that for every 1,000 pounds of mercury released into the environment , there is a consequential 61 percent increase in NN rates . With thimerosal - containing NN shots now being administered to NNS as young as six months old , it is highly plausible that ASD - associated brain damage is still occurring as a result of mercury being injected directly into muscle tissue . text: • Mymetics NNP - CD NN development project based on Mymetics ’ virosome NN carrier platform , will evaluate different rationally designed NN - CoV - 2 antigens for an effective and safe virosome - based NN - CD NN • The European NN infrastructure , TRANSVAC2 , funded by the European Commission through the Horizon 2020 framework , will provide Mymetics access to high quality technical NN development services in the fields of antigen production , analytics and animal models EPALINGES , SWITZERLAND / ACCESSWIRE / June 11 , 2020 / Mymetics Corporation ( OTCQB : MYMX ) , a pioneer and leader in the NN and development of virosome - based NNS against NN threatening and NN disabling diseases , announced today that its subsidiary , Mymetics SA , has received the confirmation to receive access to the European NN infrastructure TRANSVAC2 services for the evaluation and development of virosome - based NNS against NNP - CD , the NN caused by NNP - CoV - 2 . Since April , Mymetics has started the investigation for the rapid development of a NNP - CD virosome - based NN and is thereby partnering with leading academic institutions to start evaluating the most suitable antigens . Through TRANSVAC2 , Mymetics will VB access to pre-agreed services that Mymetics has requested and are specifically related to NNP - CoV - 2 antigen production and animal models . Mymetics Corporation ( OTCQB : MYMX ) is a Swiss based biotechnology NN , with a NN lab in the Netherlands , focused on the development of next - generation preventative NNS for infectious and NN disabling diseases . It currently has several NNS in its pipeline , among which are the HIV - 1/ AIDS , intra-nasal Influenza and malaria , and collaborative projects in the field of allergy immunotherapy and in oncology . Mymetics ’ core technology and expertise are in the use of virosomes , lipid - based carriers containing functional fusion viral proteins and natural membrane proteins , in combination with rationally designed antigens . The NN ’s NNS are designed to induce protection against early transmission and infection , focusing on both the mucosal and serum immune response . For further NN , please visit www.mymetics.com . TRANSVAC2 is European NN NN and development ( R&D ) infrastructure that aims to accelerate the development of safe , effective and affordable NNS , as they are CD of the most successful and cost - effective public NN tools for NN prevention . However , NN development is NN - consuming and complex , requiring a combination of specialised skills and technical capacities not readily available at a single organisation . In order to facilitate access to these skills and capacities , and to promote collaborations in the European NN landscape TRANSVAC2 offers high quality technical services across four different service platforms : Technology ( for process development and GMP production ) , Immunocorrelates & Systems Biology , Animal models , and support for Clinical Trials . TRANSVAC2 has received funding from the European Union ’s Horizon 2020 NN and innovation programme under grant agreement N° 730964 . text: Pharma is looking to reset its image with NN - CD NNS and treatments , but landmines loom — with pricing likely the biggest . The halo from pharma ’s rapid response in NN and discovery — and the hope that a NN or effective treatments will allow the NN to return to some sort of normal — has propelled the industry ’s reputation at an all - NN high . Forty percent of Americans say their opinion of the pharma industry has turned positive during the NN - CD NN , according to The Harris Poll . However , pricing lurks just beyond the lab . Just this week in NN , CD well - VBN pundit posited in a Forbes column that the industry ’s reputation hinges on the pricing of Gilead Sciences ' NN remdesivir , while another touted Pfizer CEO Albert Bourla ’s promise to not price its NN too high in part because “ NNS will not forget if you do that . ” Yet in the same Axios article , Bourla is quoted as saying the NN represents a “ huge commercial opportunity ” for Pfizer . Industry experts say it ’s a safe bet that other pharma NNS are wrangling with the same contradictory issues . RELATED : Can the price be JJ ? With the NN watching , Gilead faces a no-win decision on remdesivir Stewart Lyman , a biotech and pharma consultant , VBD while NNS and researchers will be satisfied with just the discovery of a NN , executives at the top of pharma NNS will likely VB more . “ I suspect they will be very sensitive to not gouging because there will be both political pressure and pressure from the other NNS to not do that this CD NN , ” VBD Lyman , who is RB a former scientist at Immunex , now owned by Amgen . “ ( But ) they ’re VBG to be looking for something in return , " he added . " Exactly how that gets sorted out , I do n’t VB , but PRP can easily imagine a quid pro quo of some type where they say ‘ yes , we ’re giving this to you for cheap but let ’s not have any price controls ’ ” on other drugs in the future . The Harris Poll Managing Director Rob Jekielek VBD pricing alone , whether Gilead 's remdesivir or NNS , has n't been the key to pharma 's improved reputation during the NN . Pricing has been a top three issue in Harris Poll surveys since March , but NNS and treatments — especially NNS — are what 's driving the hockey - stick spike in the industry 's reputation . The bigger pricing issue will be affordability once NNS and treatments are released , he VBD , although as he pointed out , that will be a more integrated issue across industries including pharma , insurance , pharmacy benefit managers and others . " If a NN or NN exists , but Americans ca n’t afford to VB it , especially the most vulnerable or at NN populations — for example , lower income , minority , or living in more densely populated areas — it will likely be a major issue , " Jekielek VBD . Of course , pricing is n’t the only hurdle pharma NNS face in navigating their reputations through developing and delivering NN - CD NNS and treatments . Managing expectations — for instance , avoiding overpromising and underdelivering on a NN 's timeline — is another important consideration , VBD N. Craig Smith , the chaired professor of ethics and JJ responsibility at INSEAD graduate business school in France . Smith pointed to JJ access to NNS and treatments , along with manufacturing and distribution issues , as other challenges . He co-authored an MIT Sloan Management Review article about the liability of the pharma industry 's competition - based model in NN - CD drug development . “ There are still questions around how drugs and NN VBP made available , who gets them RB and what prices are charged , but I do VB there ’s a great opportunity here for the industry to come out looking a whole lot better than it has in recent NNS , ” Smith VBD . Safety and efficacy of the medicines is yet another consideration . While Operation Warp Speed in both name and effort seems to be focused on speed , Lyman VBD , safety and efficacy are both more important . “ Coming up with and launching a NN fast — but CD that is neither safe or efficacious or is just CD of those — MD be an unmitigated disaster , ” he VBD . “ Not just for the NN - CD programs , but for every other NN made these days . Because then you ’re VBG to VB NNS afraid , pushed by these anti-vaccine groups , and starting to question the safety and efficacy of other NNS . ” RELATED : CD NN - CD opportunity for pharma ? A chance to bolster its reputation , Lilly CEO VBZ Jane Sarasohn - Kahn , a NN economist with NNP - NNP and blogger at NNP Populi , agreed about the NN concerns . She has already begun to VB shifts in opinions in the past few weeks as the NN wears on . “ There ’s been an erosion in public support in the U.S. for NNS — we ’ve seen challenges in getting NNS signed up into trials , and a growing chasm between folks who MD plan to take advantage of a NN - CD NN versus those who MD not , ” she VBD in an email . Still , pricing is top of mind not just for pharma NNS but for NN officials . Consumer pricing bills in both the U.S. House and Senate seek to limit NNS from profiting during national emergencies . That includes drug NNS and MD impose a 10 % profit margin for treatments or NNS . However , Anthony Fauci , M.D. , head of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases , cautioned at BIO this week that “ the federal NN should n’t force drug NNS to lower the costs of NN - CD NNS and treatments but should encourage fair pricing , ” according to a Bloomberg report . Where does that leave the industry ? In a delicate spot . As Forbes contributor John LaMattina summed up in his column about the importance of Gilead 's pricing decision , saying that it “ will set the tone for the NNP - CD NNS and drugs that will follow . It will RB impact the reputation of the whole industry . It ’s not an easy decision . Let ’s hope they VBP it JJ . ”

text: CAMBRIDGE , Mass . -- An experimental NN against the NN showed encouraging results in very early testing , triggering hoped - for immune responses in eight healthy , middle - aged volunteers , its maker announced Monday . NN volunteers given either a low or medium dose of the NN by Cambridge , Massachusetts - based Moderna Inc. had antibodies similar to those seen in NNS who have recovered from NN - CD . In the next phase of the NN , led by the U.S. National Institutes of NNP , researchers will try to determine which dose is best for a definitive experiment that they aim to start in July . In all , 45 NNS have received CD or CD shots of the NN , which was being tested at three different doses . The kind of detailed antibody results needed to assess responses are only available on eight volunteers so far . The NN seems safe , the NN VBD , but much more extensive testing is needed to VB if it remains so . A high dose version is being dropped after spurring some short - term side effects . The results have not been published and are only from the JJ of three stages of testing that NNS and drugs normally undergo . U.S. NN officials have launched a project called “ Operation Warp Speed ” to develop a NN and hopefully have 300 million doses by January . Worldwide , about a dozen NN candidates are in the JJ stages of testing or nearing it . NN officials have VBN that if all goes well , studies of a potential NN might wrap up by very late this NN or early next NN . More than 4.7 million infections and 315,000 deaths from the NN have been confirmed worldwide since it emerged in China late last NN . There are no specific approved treatments , although several are being used on an emergency basis after showing some promise in preliminary testing . text: “ Roadmap on NN ” outlines 3 NN plan for boosting “ NN confidence ” and advancing “ electronic tracking ” A report published by the European Commission in late 2019 reveals that the EU has been looking to increase the scope and power of NN programmes since well before the current “ NN ” . The endpoint of the Roadmap is , among JJ other things , to introduce a “ common NN card / passport ” for all EU citizens . This proposal will be appearing before the commission in 2022 , with a “ feasibility NN ” set to run from 2019 through 2021 ( meaning , as of now , it ’s about halfway through ) . text: Rising mumps NNS in vaccinated populations in the NNP NNPS over the past decade have raised doubts about mumps NN efficacy . Here , Lewnard et al. examined these outbreaks using mumps NN effectiveness data and dynamic transmission modeling . They VBD that the increase in mumps NNS is more consistent with loss of NN protection over NN , rather than incomplete protection against an evolving NN population or lack of immune response to the NN . Their work RB suggested that a third NN dose MD extend protection , which MD prove useful in designing a clinical action plan to prevent the spread of mumps . After decades of declining mumps incidence amid widespread NN , the NNP NNPS and other developed NNS have experienced a resurgence in mumps NNS over the last decade . Outbreaks affecting vaccinated individuals and communities with high NN coverage have prompted concerns about the effectiveness of the live attenuated NN currently in use . It is unclear whether immune protection wanes or whether the NN protects inadequately against currently circulating mumps NN lineages . Synthesizing data from six studies of mumps NN effectiveness , we estimated that NN - derived immune protection against mumps wanes on average 27 NNS ( 95 % confidence interval , 16 to 51 NNS ) after NN . After accounting for this waning , we VBD no evidence that the emergence of heterologous NN genotypes contributed to NNS in NN effectiveness over NN . A mathematical model of mumps transmission confirmed the central role of waning immunity to the NN in the re-emergence of mumps NNS . Outbreaks from 2006 to the present among young adults , and outbreaks in the late 1980s and early 1990s among adolescents , aligned with peaks in mumps susceptibility of these age groups predicted to be due to loss of NN - derived protection . In contrast , evolution of mumps NN strains escaping immune pressure MD be expected to VB a higher proportion of NNS among NNS , not adolescents and young adults as observed . Routine use of a third NN dose at 18 NNS of age , or booster dosing throughout adulthood , MD be a strategy to prevent mumps re-emergence and should be assessed in clinical trials . Over the last decade , mumps outbreaks have thwarted the goal of eliminating indigenous or nonimported mumps NN transmission in the NNP NNPS by the NN 2010 ( 1 , 2 ) . Whereas more than 90 % of U.S. - born NNS experienced mumps infections by 20 NNS of age in the prevaccine era ( 3 ) , incidence declined substantially after licensure of a live attenuated NN ( the Jeryl Lynn NN ) in 1967 , in particular after the 1977 recommendation for its routine use among infants as part of the NNS - mumps - rubella ( MMR ) NN ( 2 ) . Outbreaks among vaccinated middle school– and high school–aged NNS arose in the late 1980s , followed by sustained reductions in incidence after NNS were recommended to receive a second MMR dose at 4 to 6 NNS of age ( 4 ) . However , an ongoing resurgence in mumps NNS began with a series of outbreaks on NN campuses in 2006 ( 2 ) . An older age of infection ( ages 18 to 29 NNS , compared to the prevaccine average of 5 to 9 NNS ) has been a defining feature of these outbreaks ( 5 ) , similar to recent occurrences in Canada , western Europe , and Asian NNS with routine MMR NN ( 6 –9 ) . These circumstances are troubling on CD fronts . RB , as JJ as 10 % of mumps infections acquired after puberty MD VB severe complications including orchitis , meningitis , and deafness , in contrast to a milder clinical course in NNS that typically involves fever and parotid gland swelling ( 10 ) . Second , most mumps NNS in recent outbreaks have been reported among young adults who received CD NN doses as recommended ( 11 ) . This observation has prompted concerns about suboptimal performance of the Jeryl Lynn NN currently in use ( 12 ) . It is unclear whether recent outbreaks in vaccinated communities are due to the waning of NN - derived immunity or to the emergence of mumps NN strains escaping NN - driven immunological pressure . Distinguishing between these possibilities is critical to policy - makers and members of the scientific and medical communities : At issue is whether the re-emergence of mumps can be prevented by modifying NN dosing schedules or whether a JJ NN must instead be developed ( 12 ) . To this end , we sought to distinguish waning of NN - derived protection from JJ - term NNS in NN effectiveness against circulating mumps strains using data from six epidemiological studies of mumps NN effectiveness performed over past decades in the NNP NNPS and Europe ( table S1 ) . Pooling data from these studies , we tested whether the strength of NN - derived immune protection declines with NN since receipt of the NN — a pattern that MD suggest NN waning — and whether the degree of protection has changed over recent decades amid shifts in the circulating population of mumps NN lineages . We then measured the potential impact of the waning of NN - derived immunity on the susceptibility of the U.S. population to mumps over the decades since NN licensure and used mathematical models to assess whether recent mumps NN transmission dynamics are more consistent with hypotheses of waning immunity or NN escape . Specifically , we compared expected age - specific infection incidence in stochastic simulations of mumps transmission within CD hypothetical vaccinated populations . The JJ was subject to waning protection based on our estimates of the duration of NN - derived immunity ; the second experienced durable protection but confronted mumps NN strains against which NN provided low degrees of protection . We used our findings to evaluate alternative NN policies aiming to enhance protection among adults . Evidence of waning immunity in studies of NN effectiveness Uncertainty about the protective efficacy of the Jeryl Lynn mumps NN — ranging from 95 % after a single dose in randomized controlled trials ( 13 ) to < 50 % CD - dose effectiveness during recent outbreaks ( 14 ) —has undermined efforts to gauge population immunity . This variation in estimates of effectiveness permitted us to evaluate several hypotheses about the reasons mumps NNS have re-emerged among vaccinated persons ( 2 , 12 ) . Fitting a meta- regression model to data from prospective and retrospective cohort studies ( table S1 ) , we identified that the NN elapsed since receipt of an individual ’s last NN dose accounted for 66.4 % of unexplained variation in published NN effectiveness estimates ( Fig. 1 , A to C ) . Applying our estimate of the NN waning rate to a model of exponentially distributed durations of protection , we estimated that immunity persists , on average , 27.4 NNS [ 95 % confidence interval ( CI ) , 16.7 to 51.1 NNS ] after receipt of any dose . Among 96.4 % ( 95 % CI , 94.0 to 97.8 % ) of individuals expected to mount primary responses to mumps NN , we thus expected that 25 % MD lose protection within 7.9 NNS ( 95 % CI , 4.7 to 14.7 NNS ) , 50 % within 19.0 NNS ( 95 % CI , 11.2 to 35.4 NNS ) , and 75 % within 38.0 NNS ( 95 % CI , 22.4 to 70.8 NNS ) . Synthesis of prospective and retrospective cohort studies estimating the relative NN of clinical mumps in vaccinated and unvaccinated individuals . We illustrate the results of our meta - analysis of studies of mumps NN effectiveness , from which we estimated rates of NN waning . ( A ) Shown here is how estimates of NN effectiveness ( defined as CD minus the relative NN ( RR ) of experiencing mumps for a vaccinated individual , relative to an unvaccinated individual ) differ across the six studies analyzed here . NN since last dose accounts for 66.4 % of residual variation in estimates after accounting for random sources of between - NN heterogeneity . Points representing NN - level estimates are scaled in size to reflect differences in sample size . Lines signify 95 % confidence intervals ( CIs ) ; arrows indicate where values rounded to the nearest hundredth equal zero . ( B ) At 6 months after NN receipt ( the earliest NN point assessed in primary studies ) , we estimate that 96.4 % ( 94.0 to 97.8 % ) of recipients are protected ; we apply this as our estimate of the probability of NN take . ( C ) A parsimonious model of exponentially distributed durations of protection predicts loss of protection after , on average , NNS ( 95 % CI , 16.7 to 51.1 ) , as indicated by the yellow - plotted area . The blue - plotted area illustrates the distribution of times to loss of protection for vaccinated individuals , generated by pooling exponential distributions parameterized using estimates of ω . ( D ) Contrary to the hypothesis of reduced effectiveness against diverse mumps genotypes currently in circulation , we did not identify evidence of a decline in NN effectiveness over NN , whereas evidence of waning NN - derived immunity persisted in a model adjusting for calendar NN . Unadjusted estimates of the relative NN of clinical mumps given NN — and estimates adjusted for NN since NN , NNS since 1964 , and doses received — are calculated via meta- regression using incidence data from the original studies ( 13 , 46–50 ) . ( E ) Using this meta - regression framework , we identified no difference ( posterior CD - sided P > 0.1 ) in the waning rate ( as defined by the inverse of the association between NN since NN and relative NN of mumps given NN ; VB Materials and Methods ) after receipt of a JJ or second dose ( 95 % CI , 33 % decrease to 72 % increase in the relative NN of mumps given NN per log NN since NN ; posterior CD - sided P > 0.1 ) . The gradual replacement of predominantly A - genotype mumps NN in the prevaccine era by mixed genotypes after NN introduction has RB been suspected to contribute to diminished protection . However , we VBD no evidence for a decline in NN effectiveness over the NNS 1965 to 2006 , in particular after controlling for the effect of NN waning ( Fig. 1D ) . Whereas we estimated a nonsignificant 1.29 ( 95 % CI , 0.70 to 2.37 ) –fold increase in the relative NN of infection given NN for each log NN after 1964 in unadjusted analyses , this trend did not persist ( adjusted relative NN , 0.85 ; 95 % CI , 0.56 to 1.30 ) after controlling for longer NN since NN among older - age subjects in later studies . Moreover , we did not identify a difference in the duration of protection after a JJ dose of NN as compared to the duration of protection after a second dose ( Fig. 1E ) . Whereas second doses were originally recommended to bolster immunity in case of failed “ take ” of the JJ dose , our findings suggested that the second dose RB restores immunity to the degree achieved before waning of the JJ dose , thus extending protection to older ages . Together , our findings support the central role of waning immune protection as a driver of variation in NN performance . NNS in population susceptibility to mumps NN after NN introduction To understand the epidemiologic context of mumps resurgence in older age groups , we assessed how waning NN - derived immunity and declining rates of natural transmission have affected the susceptibility of the U.S. population over the decades since NN introduction . We inferred the degree of immune protection as of 1967 , when the NN was licensed , by fitting a mathematical model ( table S2 and fig . S1 ) to reproduce epidemiological dynamics in the prevaccine era at steady NN ( 15 ) . We estimated that the basic reproductive number ( R ) of mumps in the NNP NNPS — the number of infections expected to result from an initial index case in a fully susceptible population — was 4.79 before NN rollout , in agreement with previous estimates of 3 to 7 for high - income settings in the 20th century ( 16 , 17 ) . Allowing for loss of naturally acquired immunity did not improve model fit ( 15 ) , consistent with longer - term persistence of high antibody titers after natural infection in comparison to NN in NNS ( 18 ) . The ongoing resurgence in mumps among young adults corresponded to cohort - specific NNS in susceptibility resulting from NN waning and declining transmission over the decades since NN rollout ( Fig. 2 and fig . S2 ) . We estimated that 52.8 % ( 95 % CI , 41.6 to 63.1 % ) of adults ages 20 to 24 NNS and 52.6 % ( 95 % CI , 42.4 to 61.3 % ) of adults ages 25 to 29 NNS were susceptible to mumps NN infection in 2006 at the outset of the ongoing resurgence , in contrast to 33.8 % ( 95 % CI , 30.4 to 37.6 % ) and 25.2 % ( 95 % CI , 22.8 to 27.5 % ) , respectively , as of 1990 and < 10 % in each age group before NN introduction . Susceptibility has RB permeated older age groups amid the replacement of cohorts that experienced mumps as NNS . Whereas most individuals ages 65 NNS and older had natural immunity as of 2016 , we estimated that 29.2 % ( 95 % CI , 24.7 to 32.3 % ) of those ages 40 to 64 NNS were at NN of infection . Mumps incidence and estimates of population susceptibility over NN . Here , we illustrate NNS in the proportion of the population , by age , predicted to be susceptible to mumps on the basis of the estimated waning rate of NN - derived immune protection and the incidence of mumps infection in the population . ( A ) Overall rates of reported NNS declined after NN licensure in 1967 , punctuated by outbreaks primarily among adolescents from 1984 to 1992 and recent outbreaks ( 2006 onward ) centered among young adults . These outbreaks have corresponded with ( B ) peaks in the model - inferred proportion of individuals susceptible to mumps infection at 10 to CD and 20 to 29 NNS of age , respectively , and ( C ) reductions in the proportion of infections that VBP NNS and are reported because of NN protection against NNS . ( D ) NNS in the proportion of individuals susceptible to infection across different ages are plotted against rates of reported NNS . In a further validation of model predictions , the emergence and disappearance of mumps outbreaks among adolescents during the late 1980s and early 1990s corresponded to a transient increase in predicted susceptibility at ages 10 to CD NNS ( Fig. 2 ) . We estimated that susceptibility at ages 10 to 14 NNS peaked in 1991 , when 45.8 % ( 95 % CI , 39.3 to 52.4 % ) of NNS in this age group were at NN for infection , together with 43.0 % ( 95 % CI , 37.3 to 49.0 % ) of adolescents ages 15 to CD NNS . These estimates reflect 2.85 ( 95 % CI , 2.65 to 3.30 ) –fold and 3.96 ( 95 % CI , 3.43 to 4.52 ) –fold increases in age - specific susceptibility , respectively , compared to the prevaccine era . Whereas breakthrough outbreaks beginning in the 1980s were hypothesized at that NN to reflect inadequate responses of NNS to their JJ NN dose ( CD ) , our findings instead suggest that NN waning and declining natural exposure explain why adolescents were the population at highest NN for infection at that NN . We estimated that , as of 2016 , the prevalence of susceptibility among NNS ages 10 to 14 NNS declined to 34.8 % ( 95 % CI , 24.3 to 45.7 % ) because of the recommendation in 1989 for NNS to receive a second dose at ages 4 to 6 NNS ( 4 ) . Whereas most adolescents experiencing NNS during the initial resurgence had received CD dose of NN in keeping with the recommendations at that NN ( 20 , 21 ) , recent outbreaks have predominantly included individuals eligible to receive CD doses ( fig. S3 ) . Thus , the increasing age of infection in the NNP NNPS more likely tracks with NNS due to waning immunity after receipt of the second dose rather than a continuation of NNS within a single , underimmunized cohort . These findings hold in sensitivity analyses assuming 1 and 2 % annual declines in reporting effort ( corresponding to 39 and 63 % overall reductions in NN reporting by 2017 ) over the decades since NN introduction ( figs. S4 and S5 ) . Our analyses have suggested that reduced NN effectiveness relates primarily to waning protection rather than the emergence of mumps NN genotypes escaping NN - driven immunity . However , our ability to compare these hypotheses using data from previous studies is limited by a lack of data about genotype -specific protection . To better understand whether recent outbreaks are more consistent with NN waning or viral escape , we used a stochastic transmission model to compare expected epidemiologic dynamics under these scenarios in the NN 2006 , when the ongoing resurgence began . Using the approach taken above to update population immunity and transmission parameters in the absence of waning NN immunity ( figs. S6 and S7 ) , we simulated the spread of mumps NN strains against which the NN provided partial protection in a population of 1 million . Under age - structured JJ mixing patterns that formerly caused mumps NNS to center among school - aged NNS , waning of NN protection is a necessary mechanism to account for shifts in the age distribution of NNS toward adolescence and young adulthood . We VBD that strains capable of NN escape MD be expected to VB higher - than - observed incidence among younger NNS ( Fig. 3 , A to E ) . In contrast to the median age of mumps NNS of 22 NNS reported in 2006 , the predicted median age of NNS approached 14.2 NNS ( 95 % CI , 8.3 to 21.7 NNS ) as strain - specific NN effectiveness declined to 0 % . Although strains with lower ability to escape immune pressure MD not concentrate to such an extent among NNS , we expected such strains to VB low incidence in a population unaffected by waning immunity ( Fig. 3 F ) . Model - predicted overall rates of mumps incidence exceeded reported rates at lower degrees of cross-protection . As compared to predictions under scenarios of viral escape , model - predicted dynamics under NN waning provided a closer match to reported overall and age - specific incidence , with an expected median age of 22.3 NNS ( 95 % CI , 17.7 to 26.3 NNS ) among NNS . Anticipated transmission dynamics under scenarios of NN escape and NN waning . Here , we use a stochastic simulation model to predict the epidemiology of mumps outbreaks under the scenario of mumps NN escaping NN - induced immune pressure and the scenario of waning NN - derived immunity . ( A ) A stochastic model of an emerging NN - escape strain of mumps NN in a vaccinated population predicts excess incidence in young age groups , in keeping with their higher historical burden of mumps . ( B ) In contrast , the fit of a model incorporating waning NN - derived immunity matches the observed age distribution . ( C ) Higher overall incidence rates and ( D ) a younger age distribution of NNS are predicted when immune responses to the NN offer minimal cross-protection against the circulating strain , as compared to the fit of the model with waning NN immunity . ( E ) Whereas the model with a viral - escape ( VE ) strain can reproduce the age distribution of NNS at low degrees of immunological mismatch , ( F ) lower - than - reported incidence is expected under this scenario , again in contrast to the fit of a model with waning NN immunity . Lines in ( E ) and ( F ) signify 95 % CIs . If NN - derived immunity wanes or confers shorter - lasting protection against genotypes currently in circulation as compared to those circulating in 1967 , then administering additional NN doses MD VB VB transmission by extending immune protection to older ages . On the basis of analyses of the effective reproductive number ( R ) , or the number of JJ infectious NNS emerging from a single infectious case under prevailing levels of immunity , we VBD that protection afforded by CD NN doses alone is unlikely to support elimination of endemic mumps NN transmission from the NNP NNPS in the JJ term . If R stays below 1.0 , then epidemics are unlikely to be sustained in the JJ term ; because birth cohorts exposed to high rates of transmission in the 20th century are replaced by individuals whose protection comes only through NN , we expect R to approach 1.11 ( 95 % CI , 1.04 to 1.13 ; Fig. 4 ) . Although administering a third NN dose by 18 NNS of age MD not necessarily confer NN - JJ protection based on our estimate of the NN to loss of immunity , we nonetheless predict that this intervention MD extend protection through young adulthood , thereby protecting age groups at NN in recent outbreaks . Low ( 56 % ) uptake of a third dose matching adult compliance with recommended tetanus - diptheria toxoid booster doses MD be expected to sustain R around 0.88 ( 95 % CI , 0.83 to 0.91 ) , based on transmission dynamics in the NNP NNPS as of 2016 . Under a more optimistic scenario of 88 % third - dose coverage — where third - dose uptake equates second - dose uptake among already - immunized individuals — we expect R to approach 0.77 ( 95 % CI , 0.72 to 0.79 ) as cohorts previously exposed to high transmission rates age out of the population . Age - specific immunity and transmission dynamics under CD - and three - dose NN schedules . Waning NN - derived protection in the population raises the question of how additional NN doses MD affect mumps transmission . To address this question , we evaluated several scenarios . ( A ) Cohorts over 40 NNS of age as of 2016 were exposed to endemic transmission before and shortly after NN rollout and likely retain NN - JJ protection . However , a population protected only by CD - dose NN MD be expected to experience high prevalence of susceptibility over 20 NNS of age . ( B and C ) Our modeling suggests that the duration of protection can be extended through young adulthood by adding a third dose around 18 NNS of age , whereas routine booster doses every 10 or 20 NNS MD be expected to sustain longer - term protection . Lines and shaded areas delineate median estimates and 95 % CIs , respectively . ( D ) Under transmission dynamics estimated as of 2016 , protection in young adult age groups achieved through the use of a third NN dose is expected to reduce the effective reproductive number ( R ) below 1 . We , however , predict R to approach 1.10 under the CD - dose schedule as cohorts that experienced high rates of mumps infection age out of the population ; larger reductions in R are sustained at higher coverage and with more frequent dosing . Colors are the same as in ( A ) to ( C ) . R , basic reproductive number . ( E ) In turn , these extensions of protection provide a stronger barrier against emergence of strains escaping NN immunity . A JJ strain with 8.5 % ( 95 % CI , 7.6 to 9.8 % ) probability of evading NN - induced immunity and infecting a NN - protected individual MD be expected to succeed under a three - dose schedule with low coverage . We , however , estimate that a JJ strain MD require 22.9 % ( 95 % CI , 16.4 to 29.7 % ) probability of infecting such an individual to emerge in a population with 88 % uptake of the third dose and 10 - NN boosters . Lines denote 95 % CIs , and shaded areas represent distributions around R estimates . Whereas we estimated that most older adults are currently immune to mumps NN because of previous infection , our modeling suggested that neither a CD - dose nor a three - dose NN program MD be expected to protect more than 50 % of adults beyond the age of 40 NNS in the JJ term . This concern MD motivate the use of routine booster doses in adulthood ( Fig. 4 ) . On the basis of our model , we expect that administering additional doses every 10 or 20 NNS MD lead to sustained protection in , at minimum , 68.0 % ( 95 % CI , 58.5 to 77.6 % ) and 55.2 % ( 95 % CI , 44.1 to 68.4 % ) of the population , respectively , under a scenario of 88 % NN coverage ; at the lower ( 56 % ) coverage level , we estimated protection among , at minimum , 59.0 % ( 95 % CI , 48.2 to 71.2 % ) and 45.5 % ( 95 % CI , 34.3 to 60.5 % ) of adults with dosing every 10 or 20 NNS , respectively . Maintaining high prevalence of immunity in the population through repeated dosing MD RB VB to contain emergence of JJ mumps NN strains ( Fig. 4E ) . To sustain R ≥ 1 under three - dose schedules , we estimated that an emerging strain MD require , at minimum , 8.5 % ( 95 % CI , 7.6 to 9.8 % ) to 15.7 % ( 95 % CI , 11.9 to 20.3 % ) probability of causing infection in exposed persons otherwise protected by NN . Adding booster doses every 10 NNS increased this threshold probability to between 16.6 % ( 95 % CI , 12.5 to 20.8 % ) and 22.9 % ( 95 % CI , 16.4 to 29.7 % ) at varying degrees of NN coverage . Resurgent outbreaks centered among young adults have brought renewed attention to mumps after decades of progress toward its elimination from the NNP NNPS ( 2 , 12 ) . Understanding why NNS have re-emerged is essential for determining how to contain the NN through NN . Our analyses show that NN - derived immune protection wanes over NN . We estimate the rate of waning and demonstrate that this waning immunity accounts for susceptibility in the age groups experiencing outbreaks over the decades since NN introduction in the NNP NNPS . In contrast , NNS in the circulating genotypes of mumps NN over this same period have not been associated with reductions in NN effectiveness ; moreover , our modeling suggests that mumps NN strains escaping NN protection MD be expected to VB disproportionate incidence among younger NNS , which has not been observed in most recent outbreaks . Guided by these outcomes , our model shows that routine use of a third NN dose around 18 NNS of age , with or without regular dosing in adulthood , MD VB maintain immune protection in the population . Distinguishing between the contributions of NN waning and the emergence of NN - escape NN strains to mumps resurgence helps inform whether JJ NNS are needed to VB transmission ( 22 , 23 ) . Our findings that NN effectiveness has not declined amid the replacement of genotype A mumps viruses ( from which the Jeryl Lynn NN strain was derived ) , and that the age distribution of recent NNS is inconsistent with expectations under NN escape , are in agreement with several lines of evidence that mumps NN protects broadly against heterologous strains ( 24 ) . Neutralizing antibody responses to the Jeryl Lynn strain are effective in vitro against wild - type mumps NN strains responsible for recent outbreaks among vaccinated individuals ( 25 , 26 ) , and genetic distinctions have not been identified between strains isolated from vaccinated and unvaccinated mumps patients ( 27 ) . High efficacy and effectiveness estimates for both the Jeryl Lynn ( genotype A–derived ) and Urabe ( genotype B–derived ) NNS against clinical illness caused by heterologous mumps genotypes further substantiate the notion of cross-neutralizing or monotypic immune responses ( 12 ) . Although the efficacy of a third dose has not been assessed in clinical trials , several observations suggest effectiveness of extended NN schedules . Although congregated U.S. military populations resemble high - NN groups based on their age distribution and close - contact environments , no outbreaks have been reported in the military since a policy of administering an MMR dose to incoming recruits , regardless of NN history , was adopted in 1991 ( 28 ) . In addition , receiving a third dose was associated with protection in a recent observational NN after a third - dose NN undertaken in response to a NN campus outbreak ( 29 ) , building on limited evidence from previous studies where third doses were only administered at the tail end of outbreaks ( 30–33 ) . Trials demonstrating the clinical effectiveness of adult NN doses remain ideal to guide policy around the benefits of routine or reactive use of third doses and MD improve our understanding of immunological correlates of protection ( 34–36 ) . Such trials — or further observational studies — will RB play an important role in establishing the duration of protection after third or additional doses in adulthood . Modifying MMR NNS to improve the magnitude or duration of immune responses against mumps NN MD RB improve protection . Notably , the mumps component of the NN induces lower - avidity antibody responses , and weaker specific memory B cell proliferation , than the NNS and rubella components ( 37 , 38 ) . Several limitations of the analysis should be considered . Our use of aggregated rather than individual - level data from NN effectiveness studies contributed to an imprecise estimate of the NN to loss of immunity , in turn limiting the precision of our estimates of population susceptibility . Individual - level data from postlicensure NN studies MD support better inferences about the magnitude and duration of NN protection , thus aiding policy decisions . Identifying immunological correlates of protection from such data sets MD RB aid evaluations of alternative NN schedules and measurements of population immunity . Second , we lack data on genotype - specific incidence that MD VB us infer differential protection of the Jeryl Lynn NN against circulating strains . Epidemiological studies of outbreaks caused by distinct NN lineages , and in populations exposed to different circulating mumps viruses , can better characterize genotype specificity in the strength or duration of NN protection . Last , our analysis addresses mumps epidemiology in the NNP NNPS , where prevalence of immunity within particular birth cohorts MD differ in relation to settings that introduced routine mumps NN later or use different NN schedules . The burden of NNS and prevalence of immunity across ages or birth cohorts should be considered as a basis to guide NN policy within specific NNS . Analyzing nationally aggregated incidence data sets RB limited our ability to investigate how geographic or socioeconomic differences in NN uptake and contact rates contribute to the dynamics of focal outbreaks , as might occur in close - contact settings such as NN dormitories ( 39 , 40 ) . However , our inferences about NN waning and the changing age distribution of mumps NNS offer insight into why mumps resurgence has been possible throughout geographically and socioeconomically distinct communities . In this regard , the widespread re-emergence of mumps in NN - compliant communities stands in stark contrast to the focal re-emergence of NNS in communities with low NN coverage ( 11 ) . NNS in the epidemiology of mumps have implications for NN surveillance . Diminished clinical awareness of mumps , expectations that it appears in pediatric rather than adult populations , and protection against NNS in vaccinated individuals ( 41 ) MD limit routine detection of NNS and thus bias NN reporting . Serological surveys have provided evidence of higher - than - reported rates of mumps NN infection in the NNP NNPS before 2006 ( 28 , 42 ) . The tendency to identify outbreak - associated NNS through contact tracing MD RB favor detection of NNS in NN campuses and other closely connected populations , underscoring the importance of epidemiological surveillance to identify infections occurring in the community . The ongoing resurgence in mumps among young adults has undermined previous enthusiasm about near - term elimination of this NN from the NNP NNPS ( 1 ) . Our analysis suggests that vaccinated individuals lose protection against infection on average 27 NNS after receipt of their last dose and that this rate of NN waning explains susceptibility in adolescent and young adult cohorts at the NN of postlicensure outbreaks in these age groups . Re-emergence of mumps among older , previously vaccinated individuals whose immunity has waned parallels recent experience with varicella outbreaks affecting immunized communities as a result of waning NN - derived protection ( 43 ) . As demonstrated in mumps epidemiology , immunity in previously infected cohorts MD buffer transmission and delay breakthrough epidemics from occurring until decades after NN introduction . We expect population susceptibility to mumps to continue increasing as transient NN - derived immunity supersedes previous infection as the main determinant of mumps susceptibility in the U.S. population . These observations indicate the need for either innovative clinical trial designs to measure the benefit of extending NN dosing schedules or JJ NNS to address the problem of waning NN - induced protection ( 44 ) . Our NN is composed of four parts . RB , we conducted a meta - analysis of six studies on mumps NN effectiveness in the NNP NNPS and Europe to assess hypotheses of waning protection and diminished effectiveness against currently circulating strains . We then applied estimates of the waning rate from this analysis to infer NNS over NN in the susceptibility of the U.S. population , accounting for NN uptake and incidence of natural infection . We integrated a system of differential equations forward from initial conditions , defined from the prevaccination endemic equilibrium ( as inferred over the NNS 1960 to 1964 ) , by NN - calculating transmission rates from reported mumps incidence . We next modeled expected transmission dynamics under scenarios of NN waning and viral escape and estimated JJ - term impacts of adult NN schedules on population susceptibility . Full technical details pertaining to our analyses are presented in Supplementary Materials and Methods ( a brief summary is provided here ) . We performed a systematic review of prospective and retrospective cohort studies calculating effectiveness of the Jeryl Lynn strain mumps NN via a PubMed search and citation tracking . Details of the studies used to infer NN effectiveness are listed in table S1 . We used an inverse variance - weighted meta- regression model , accounting for NN - level heterogeneity , to measure unadjusted and multivariate - adjusted associations of the following variables with NN - level estimates of the relative NN of infection associated with NN : ( i ) NN since receipt of the last NN dose , indicating waning NN immunity ; ( ii ) NN from 1964 ( when the Jeryl Lynn NN was developed ) to the NN of mumps exposure , indicating JJ - term NNS in NN effectiveness associated with NNS in circulating genotypes ; and ( iii ) NN doses received , with an interaction term for NN since the last dose to test for differential waning of JJ and second doses . Regression model summary statistics indicated the proportion of variance explained by these covariates . We used our estimate of the association between instantaneous NN of infection and NN since NN to fit an exponential distribution to the duration of NN - derived immune protection and used this fitted distribution as the basis for further modeling . We used a system of ordinary differential equations to describe NNS in the population of susceptible and protected persons , partitioned into those who had and had not received mumps NNS . Updating the model to address the contributions of NN and NN waning to population immunity , we RB - calculated NNS in natural immunity in the population based on the relation between reported incidence rates ( Λ ) in age group i and NN t and the force of infection to which individuals were exposed ( λ ) , the populations of susceptible unvaccinated ( S ) and vaccinated ( F ) persons , and the probabilities ( π and π , respectively ) for these individuals to experience NNS if infected . As described in Supplementary Materials and Methods , this approach allowed us to account for NNS over NN in transmission patterns leading to NN - varying estimates of the basic reproductive number . Susceptible vaccinated persons ( F ) comprised those failing to mount an immune response immediately after NN ( primary NN failure ) and those whose initial protection had waned ( secondary NN failure ) . Model parameter values and their sources are listed in table S2 . Age - specific incidence reports were collated from nationwide surveillance ( 45 ) . Our model accounted for age - structured mixing among individuals partitioned across 10 age classes ( 0 to 11 months , 1 to 4 NNS , 5 to 9 NNS , 10 to 14 NNS , 15 to CD NNS , 20 to 24 NNS , 25 to 29 NNS , 30 to 39 NNS , 40 to 64 NNS , and ≥ 65 NNS ) . Members of the ith age class encountered the force of infection cumulatively through interactions with infectious individuals ( I ) distributed across all j age classes ; the matrix C conveyed age - specific mixing patterns . We inferred starting - NN age - specific prevalence of immunity in the U.S. population ( as of 1967 ) by fitting a mathematical model of mumps transmission to recapitulate age - specific incidence in the prevaccine era at steady NN . To compare predicted incidence during an introduced outbreak against observations from the NN 2006 , we implemented stochastic realizations of extended versions of the model under scenarios where we assumed waning of immunity or circulation of strains with differential NN of infecting persons protected by NN . We assessed which scenario was more consistent with epidemiological observations on the basis of model - predicted age - specific and overall incidence rates , as well as the predicted median age of infection . We compared the JJ - term performance of different NN schedules including the addition of a third dose by 18 NNS of age and the use of routine boosters at 10 - or 20 - NN intervals through adulthood . We calculated the prevalence of age - specific immune protection achieved under these strategies and resulting values of the effective reproductive number ( R ) , describing the number of NNS an infectious individual MD be expected to VB under prevailing conditions . We RB calculated the minimum probability of immune escape a novel mumps NN strain MD need to invade a population protected under these different strategies , defined as the minimum probability of infecting a vaccinated , protected individual upon exposure such that R ≥ 1 . text: Kentucky Derby fans MD need to take some extra precautions before heading off to the races . The Indiana NNP Department of NNP is recommending that its residents VBP vaccinated against hepatitis A and take other steps to protect themselves from the illness before traveling to Kentucky or Michigan , both of which are experiencing JJ outbreaks of the viral infection . Kentucky has reported more than 300 NNS of hepatitis A since November 2017 , with 39 JJ NNS reported in the JJ week of April , according to the Kentucky Department for Public NNP . Most NNS in the NN have occurred around Louisville — the city where the Kentucky Derby is held . The famous horse race , which draws more than 150,000 NNS each NN , takes place on the JJ Saturday in NNP . " With popular tourist events coming up in other NNS , we VBP JJ Hoosiers will be traveling to areas impacted by hepatitis A , and we VBP them to be safe , " Pam Pontones , the Indiana deputy NN NN commissioner , VBD in a statement . " Getting vaccinated and thoroughly washing your hands before and after preparing food and eating and after using the restroom are simple , safe and effective ways to prevent the spread of hepatitis A . " But do you really need to VB a hepatitis A NN if you 're VBG to the Kentucky Derby ? Dr. Amesh Adalja , a senior scholar at the Johns Hopkins Center for NNP Security , VBD the Indiana recommendation is an interesting step to take , and it 's not a bad idea . " I can VB why they MD advise it , " Adalja VBD . " It 's something that 's an easy measure that can minimize NN . " [ 27 Devastating Infectious Diseases ] At the same NN , Adalja VBD Live NNP that the NN of hepatitis A probably is n't very high for the average visitor to the Derby . A number of recent U.S. hepatitis A outbreaks , including the NN in Kentucky , have occurred primarily among the homeless population and illicit - drug users — a group that MD have limited access to clean toilets and handwashing facilities , which are important in preventing the spread of hepatitis A . But hepatitis A outbreaks can RB occur through contaminated food , Adalja noted — for instance , if food workers contract the illness and handle food without properly washing their hands . ( The Kentucky hepatitis A outbreak has not been linked with contaminated food , although it was recently reported that a McDonald 's employee in Berea , Kentucky , south of Lexington , had the infection and MD have potentially spread it to customers . ) If Kentucky Derby - goers VBP to minimize their NN of getting the illness , " the NN is CD NN to do that , " Adalja VBD . Hepatitis A is a contagious liver infection caused by the hepatitis A NN , according to the Centers for NNP NNP and Prevention . The NN is spread through the " fecal - oral " route — that is , when small amounts of stool from an ill person contaminate objects , food or drinks that are then touched and ingested by another person , the CDC VBZ . For this reason , thorough handwashing — particularly after using the bathroom or changing a NN 's diaper , or before eating — can VB reduce a person 's NN of getting hepatitis A , according to the Mayo Clinic . text: As the NNP ’s NNP Defense eBook , Conflicts of Interest Undermine NNPS ’s NNP , tries to make clear , the passage of the National Childhood NNP Injury Act ( NCVIA ) in 1986 was a watershed event that emboldened NN manufacturers and their public - and private - sector accomplices — notably the Centers for NNP NNP and Prevention ( CDC ) — to systematically hide the serious damage caused by NNS . In addition to making a mockery of pre-licensing safety testing and post - marketing surveillance , these entities have regularly manipulated ( or destroyed ) data to exaggerate both the benefits and effectiveness of NN . Manufacturers have RB used their money and power to subordinate the mainstream NN , medical journals and front groups , making it possible to publish and broadcast deceptive studies that whitewash questions inconvenient to the financial bottom line . From multiple standpoints — not least of which is NNS ’s dismal NN of NN — the status quo is untenable . Three of the most urgent steps to be taken include repealing the NCVIA , eliminating NN mandates ( making both childhood and adult NN voluntary ) and addressing conflicts of interest by establishing a fully transparent and independent NN safety commission . The NCVIA has been an unmitigated disaster . As NNP York NNP law professor Mary Holland has written , the Act ’s passage has allowed the NN and NN manufacturers to ride roughshod over three important legal protections : • Free and informed consent to an invasive medical procedure • Accurate and complete NN about NN ingredients and possible side effects • The NN to sue manufacturers and medical practitioners directly in the event of injury . According to Holland , the absence of these legal protections for NN is “ striking ” compared to “ almost all other medical interventions . ” The legal protections are interrelated . For example , an individual cannot exercise truly informed consent unless he or she has access to full and unbiased NN . Recognizing this , CD provision of the NCVIA was a mandate for the CDC to develop ( and NN care providers to distribute ) patient education materials about NN risks and benefits . However , not only has the CDC repeatedly dumbed down the materials in a variety of ways , but NN suggests that JJ doctors do not comply with the legal requirement to hand out ( much less discuss ) them . Instead , providers and the NN continue to blandly assure the public that NN injuries are a “ CD in a million ” event , never mentioning that 99 % of NN injuries VBP unreported . text: Since the NNP - CD NN began , there has been a sudden and massive divergence in macroeconomic projections . For example , in early February , the spread among JJ growth forecasts for Q2 in the U.S. was 3.5 percentage points according to FocusEconomics data . By April 29 , the most optimistic forecast among the 28 institutions in our weekly NN survey saw the U.S. economy contracting 8.2 % . The most pessimistic projected a huge 65.0 % contraction — a spread of 56.8 percentage points — with an average of - 31.4 % . There are three reasons for the divergence : RB , the JJ impact and speed of policy NNS have never been higher . Second , the NN is undermining the reliability of JJ data . Finally , JJ forecasters are having to delve into the unfamiliar NN of epidemiology . The NN NN has introduced extreme uncertainty into nearly every aspect of society . Will NN care systems hold up ? Will NNS develop a NN ? Are essential workers safe ? When can regular employees VB RB to the office ? The answers to these questions — when there are answers — seem to VB daily . And with each NN the stock market ( and our hopes ) rises or falls . Since the NNP - CD NN began , we ’ve seen pervasive uncertainty manifest in a sudden and massive divergence in macroeconomic projections . For example , in early February , the spread among JJ growth forecasts for Q2 in the U.S. was 3.5 percentage points according to FocusEconomics data . By April 29 , the most optimistic forecast among the 28 institutions in our weekly NN survey saw the U.S. economy contracting 8.2 % . The most pessimistic projected a huge 65.0 % contraction — a spread of 56.8 percentage points — with an average of - 31.4 % . While most institutions expected a rebound in Q3 , some saw further declines . And in Q4 , although all economists projected growth of some form , forecasts ranged from a minimum of +1.1 % and a maximum of +70.0 % . The spreads observed in recent weeks are by far the widest recorded since we started covering the U.S. a decade ago . Looking at NNS with a longer NN horizon , the current forecast spread among analysts is far larger than at any point during the past 20 NNS , and significantly above that seen during the height of the financial crisis — the last period of extreme , prolonged JJ uncertainty . For example , during the 2008 financial crisis , both Brazil and Mexico saw the spread for annual GDP forecasts widen to close to six percentage points , before returning to under three for most of the 2010s . The percentage point spread is now well over seven percentage points . Why So Much Divergence ? The short answer to why there is so much divergence is because no NN knows for sure what is VBG to happen . Digging deeper , three key factors are causing forecasters particular difficulties . RB , the JJ impact and speed of policy NNS have never been higher . In normal times , most governments can be relied on to at least attempt to encourage JJ growth and preserve employment . Today , however , they are deliberately provoking recessions to save lives , and containment measures are crushing domestic activity . Simply miscalculating the end date of a nationwide lockdown by a couple of weeks throws annual GDP forecasts completely off - kilter . Moreover , bills which generally endure months of parliamentary ping - pong are being rushed through legislatures in days as governments and central banks race to respond to the rapid advance of the NN . JJ governments have adopted emergency powers allowing them to rule by decree . What ’s more , the fiscal and monetary stimulus being announced to palliate the downturn dwarfs that seen during the financial crisis . For JJ forecasters , keeping up with the constant flurry of measures and correctly incorporating them into models poses challenges . Second , the NN is undermining the reliability of JJ data — the bedrock of any good macroeconomic model . In particular , survey - based data of businesses and households is suffering as lockdown measures reduce response rates , amplifying sampling error . The U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics data for March , for instance , saw establishments ’ and households ’ response rates fall by nine and 10 percentage points respectively relative to their recent average . Paul Donovan , chief economist at UBS NNP Wealth Management , explained the problem this NN : “ If you are filling in survey forms in a lockdown , you are likely to be an unusual person , and possibly not representative . Sentiment affects answers to surveys . Data , IN consumer price inflation , includes restaurant prices , but restaurants are closed . What happens when you survey something that is not there ? Online spending is likely to have increased in lockdowns . Online spending MD stay higher after the lockdowns end . It MD not be properly captured in official data . ” The third reason the models are diverging so much is because JJ forecasters are having to delve into the unfamiliar NN of epidemiology to better understand the likely evolution of the NN outbreak in each country . However , this is a challenge RB for NN experts . Predicting the scope and effectiveness of future public NN interventions , or how NN care systems will respond under pressure , is tough — particularly for NNS at early stages of their epidemics . There is no firm timeline for the arrival of game - changing treatments or NNS , or clarity over the likelihood or severity of a second wave of NNS . The divergence in JJ forecasts should narrow somewhat VBG forward . Greater clarity will emerge on the effectiveness of recent stimulus , and any further fiscal or monetary measures will likely be more modest in scope . The gradual lifting of lockdowns will facilitate the collection of JJ data . Our knowledge of the NN and its spread will improve . But a return to pre-virus levels of JJ uncertainty will have to wait until a lasting solution to the NN — likely in the form of a NN — is VBN . While the NN NN poses a unique challenge to macroeconomic forecasters , the profession has faced similarly profound shocks in the past and emerged fortified . The JJ financial crisis of 2008 caught most economists napping . But the insights gained in areas such as the economics of financial contagion and the impact of unconventional monetary measures have improved the quality of today ’s forecasting models . In the same NN , NNP - CD will shine JJ light on areas such as behavioral economics — how consumer spending is affected by fear of contagion for instance — and the JJ effects of radical fiscal policy . The knowledge gained MD make the uncertainty of future JJ crises , whenever and however they come , that bit less extreme .

text: ‘ It ’s VBG to be hard . ’ We ’re RB perilously far behind . The number of JJ NNS appearing each day is swinging wildly , from 13,000 on NNP CD to 24,000 the next day , RB though much of the country remains locked down . And those are just the NNS we VBP about . Until the U.S. does a far better job of quickly figuring out who is infected , it simply wo n’t be possible to keep up with tracing . Marc Lipsitch , director of the Center for Communicable NNP Dynamics at Harvard NNP 's School of Public NNP , is pessimistic . RB if 80 percent of the country managed to trace NNS effectively — “ which MD be miraculous , ” he VBD — the remaining 20 percent MD be a constant source of JJ infections . JJ NN , not yet peer reviewed , suggests tracing MD have to catch at least half of all JJ NNS to reduce transmission RB 10 percent . “ My view is it ’s probably not VBG to work , ” Lipsitch VBD . “ But given the lack of alternatives , we have to try — and hopefully demonstrate that I ’m wrong . ” Tracing techniques have been honed over decades Technology MD VB some this NN around . Apple and Google and a half dozen other NNS are developing cellphone applications that use GPS or Bluetooth technology . These apps can alert users that they were recently near an infectious person or allow them to retrace their steps to VB if they crossed paths with a carrier . But most experts insist technology will merely support , not supplant , JJ tracing . And it MD never be as effective in the U.S. as it has been in other NNS . For starters , tech solutions are valuable only if widely adopted , and polls show Americans are skeptical and worry that apps MD infringe on data privacy . The U.S. RB has so JJ NNS that it ca n’t rely on weak crowdsourcing with limited penetration to find them all . Meanwhile , in much of Asia , previous viral outbreaks bred enough comfort and respect for tracing that there is less need for the handholding provided by JJ tracers . In a few NNS , notably China , authoritarian governments RB leave citizens little choice but to participate .

text: VB breaking NN alerts and special reports . The NN and stories that matter , delivered weekday mornings . An experimental NN NN from Oxford NNP appears to be effective at preventing NN - CD , according to findings from a small NN in six monkeys . Oxford NNS posted the preliminary findings on the NN on the preprint server bioRxiv early Thursday . Preprints are studies that have not undergone a rigorous peer - review process required for publication in medical or scientific journals . But JJ NNS have been releasing results to the public in the form of preprints because of the high level of interest surrounding potential treatments and NNS for NN - CD , the NN caused by the NN . The JJ report from Oxford NNP is based on the NN of six rhesus macaques . These monkeys are considered to be good proxies for how drugs MD work in NNS because they share a majority of their genes with humans . The animals were given half of the dose currently being tested in JJ . Those trials began on April 24 and include about 1,110 NNS . Researchers reported at least some of the monkeys developed antibodies to the NN within 14 days of being vaccinated , and all of the vaccinated animals had evidence of antibodies within 28 days . Download the NBC NNP app for full coverage of the NN outbreak What 's more , researchers VBD the NN appears to have prevented pneumonia and other lung problems in the animals after they were exposed to the NN . Still , there is no guarantee the Oxford NN will ultimately prove to be successful . Studies in humans are ongoing , and this NN team is CD of several around the globe working at an accelerated pace to find a safe and effective NN for the NN . But so far , the Oxford NN appears to hold the most promise of becoming the JJ NN to be widely accessible , if proven to work . Oxford NNS previously VBD they hope to have enough data to show the NN is effective by the beginning of June , and predicted the NN MD be produced by September .

text: Posts on JJ NN claim Bill Gates is facing a trial in India for allegedly testing NNS on NNS illegally . This is misleading . Some iterations of the claim , titled “ Bill Gates Faces Trial in India for Illegally Testing Tribal NNPS with NNPS ” , can be seen here and here . A spokesperson for the Gates Foundation confirmed to Reuters via email that the allegations in the claim are false . There is no pending lawsuit against Gates or his foundation in relation to this . The NN trial in question was not illegal , though it was later halted and has been the source of controversy in India . The claims refer to a NNP Papilloma NNP ( HPV ) NN NN conducted by the U.S. non-profit organization Program for Appropriate Technology in NNP ( PATH ) . The NN , which was financed by the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation , was cancelled in 2010 after local NN reported the death of seven girls taking part ( here , here ) . The NN was cancelled in 2010 following local NN reports highlighting the death of seven girls taking part . NNP Magazine reported that investigations carried out by a committee designated by the Indian NN later determined the deaths were unrelated to the NN demonstration : “ Five were evidently unrelated to the NN : CD girl drowned in a quarry ; another died from a snake bite ; CD committed suicide by ingesting pesticides ; and CD died from complications of malaria . The causes of death for the other CD girls were less certain : CD possibly from pyrexia , or high fever , and a second from a suspected cerebral hemorrhage . ” ( here ) On August 29 , 2013 the Indian Parliament ’s Standing Committee on NNP and Family Welfare reported the NN trial by PATH committed several irregularities , including a “ gross violation of the consent and legal requirement of consent ” ( VB page 14 here ) . After the report was released , PATH VBD they “ strongly disagree with the findings , conclusions , and tone of the released report and its disregard of the evidence and facts . ” ( here ) According to the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation ’s website , they have been working in India for over a decade , with a focus on the country ’s most vulnerable communities ( here ) . As of NNP 18 , 2020 the Foundation faces no charges in India and continues to work in the country . False . Bill Gates is not facing trial in India for an illegal NN NN . This article was produced by the Reuters Fact Check team . Read more about our work to fact - check JJ NN posts here .
